reviewText:
Putrefaction lets you play as an unnamed operative of a team whose objective is to stop the spread of a disease that turns humans into monsters. The game intro states you found a secret entrance to a base that seems full of the diseased monsters and, in true hero fashion, you assault it alone after calling in its location.
What follows is a very simple game where you face hordes of infected one after the other while trying to find the exit of each level: dull gameplay, a few perplexing design decisions and a couple of bugs make this a forgettable experience at best.

PROS:

-the graphics are modest but work well enough

-good amount of weapons

-decent gore and dismembering

-the monsters you'll be facing have enough variety to not become too boring

CONS:

-dull level design made worse by rooms and corridors that all look the same

-basic, unimpressive gameplay

-horrible enemy spawn system

-bad AI, melee enemies can't jump or climb so if you can reach, say, a tall box you'll be safe from them

-weapon sounds are tinny and weak

-some enemy animations, like jumps and dodge rolls, are clearly missing some frames

-basically no story or objectives whatsoever

-a few lingering bugs, one also makes the last boss almost unbeatable unless you read about it in the forums

-has a reload button but weapons have bottomless clips, in fact you can't reload at all

-very short, 1 hour and a half at most

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=509746690

Putrefaction claims to be inspired by the FPS games of old like Doom, well I'm sad to say they have little in common qualitywise: those old games were simple, sure, but had good levels with places to explore and secrets to uncover, nice enemies, challenging boss fights and at least some item hunting to switch things around a bit.

Let's start with the story, I'm not expecting much since it's a shooter after all but there's nothing after the intro text,nothing at all apart from a small text note at the end...why are people mutating so much that they resemble full blown aliens? Why is there an huge boss? What's up with the base itself? Why can infected spawn out of thin air like ghosts? And why do the infected disappear and their place is taken by some sort of glowing spirits in the last levels? No idea whatsoever.

But story isn't an important part of a simple shooter after all, sadly the gameplay is just as uninspired and boils down to moving towards the exit slaughtering waves of infected/spirits whenever a locked door/light barrier stops you, rinse and repeat. There are no objectives, no keys to find, no computers or switches to activate, nothing. It gets dull fast to be honest as you walk yet another nondescript corridor/room waiting for the next ambush.

All this is made worse by the nonsensical spawn system, infected can spawn anywhere, even right behind you or out of thin air one foot in front of you: this not only looks surreal and silly but also makes the game hard in an unfair way. You have no dodge or sprint moves and having a melee enemy spawning right behind you can be a disaster: it actually gets even sillier when such spawning tactics are employed by suicidal exploding enemies that will take 1/3 of your health each...when faced with them my only tactic was to put myself into a corner to make sure none'd spawn too close, but having to cheat the game this way to make it playable shows how bad this design choice is. There's also a few instances where enemies will spawn a bit far from the area you're in or refuse to leave a certain room forcing you to look for them to be able to progress.

Last but not least even a month after release there's still a few bugs the worse being one making the final boss not being affected by your weapons for about 20/30 seconds after each time you destroy its shield. I had to look it up on the forums after trying twice and wasting all my ammo only to die in return.

To sum things up no story, bland levels, simple gameplay, horrible and unfair spawning system, some nasty bugs and generally low production values make this a game I simply can't recommend: if you're looking for an old school FPS fix please look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Intro - About      A first-person zombie survival chock full of visceral violence and gore galore! This game has a variety of weapons you can scavenge for, allowing you to add a personal flair to the beautiful art of massacre. The weapons show some clear influence from Doom in their appearance-- which isn't a bad thing, of course. You can also snag melee weapons to dish out devastating damage to the daunting demonic nightmares and put them back in their place! Even with mediocre graphics and (relatively) poor controls, this game will have you constantly on edge due to the massive hords filled with different kinds of enemies-- all with their own methods of menacing you.

Pros & Cons
++  Pros
+ Fast paced
+ Chaotic fun
+ Weapon choice
+ (Somewhat) Decent graphics
+ Dismembering enemies (Always a plus in my book -Editorial Drone)

-- Cons
- Poor sound quality
- Repetitive monster designs
- Pretty bad controls
- Can't edit options on the fly
- Animations are a bit wonky

Summary     Make your way through hallways, buildings, and other such locations, fending off deadly zombie-esque critters while finding health packs to patch yourself up and some ammo for your guns. Pick up a rocket launcher and, with a few strategically placed shots, clear entire rooms full of grisly creatures, prompting a sudden downpour of blood and various sundry organs.

Personal Opinion     I didn't like this game much at first, but, after I got to a higher level and found more guns, I started to survive longer, and the intensity started to, well, intensify! The hordes are relentless and get exponentially stronger, which forced me to be constantly aware of my surroundings, scanning for health pickups and ammo drops to ensure my survival.

Final recommendation: I give this game  7/10 ! This game is well thought out--good ideas that are clearly inspired by old school classics--but the execution is mediocre at best and the game doesn't have much polish. It clearly had a lot more potential than what we see now.

reviewText:
Comparing this game to old-school FPS such as Doom, Quake, Serious Sam, Painkiller or even the more recent Killing Floor is kinda insulting for longtime pc gamers like me!

The player's movements are kinda slow. The enemies are poorly animated and always spawn in dead angles. The weapons lack punches and are badly designed. The level design is very linear unlike Doom, Quake and Serious Sam where levels were built like mazes that feature sometimes open spaces. If only it had good background music during exploration and combat.

The only enjoyable thing about the game is the gore effect which is not bad for an indie game. (+1) Also, it features lots of different enemy types and some boss fights. (+1) And at least, it's not a broken game which means I never had any crashing (+1) or clipping issues (+1).

Overall, the game feels tedious and very generic. Another typical indie FPS powered by the (unoptimized) Unity engine. In fact, the game has more in common with Slaughtering Grounds, Devils Share, Into the Dark, Prisoners of Power, Country Justice Revenge of the Redneck, Liquidator, Dark Vampires and Dracula The Days of Gore.

The title Putrefaction" says everything about the game. You can smell it from your computer screen.

Before the indie dev and its fanboys dislike or delete my review avoid the game at all cost! I wish the actual reviews on the store page could have more common sense.

This game is currently in a bundle in indiegala (as of 08/29/15) and caught my eyes enough to go pinch in and purchase a bundle having few games that I already owned.

The game is advertised as a Doom-like and unfortunately it is not... It is a Serious Sam like.  In other term, don't expect moving freely in an entire level being pursued by hordes of monsters while trying to solve some puzzles to make it to the next level... In this game (like in Serious Sam), you are trapped in a subsection of a level, have to kill every monsters that appear and then will be granted right to go to the next level subsection.  This is quite a difference of gameplay and it is probably why I never like Serious Sam and still believe that Doom 1 and 2 are the best FPS ever made (with L4D).

The control are poor or not implemented in the usual FPS way.  The left shift key does nothing which is extremely frustrating because you will expect to be able to run for your life with it.  The interaction with the surrounding is null... simply opening door and picking up ammo and life, nothing else.  The sound is average especially for detecting monsters on your back which appears out of thin air.

All of these make the game strongly outdated and still fall short from the comparison with Doom and other major old-school shooters.  I might sound a little harsh especially since Putrefaction seems to be  a one man project but the price tag of $5  is quite high for a game I would probably never play again.

I was really hoping to enjoy this game despite what the negative reviews had to say about it. Unfortunately they were quite right.

The AI is basically complete rubbish, even on the highest difficulty level. If you find a higher spot you can jump up to, or some boxes to jump behind, the melee guys got nothing on you (save for the first boss which has an impressive reach on his swing). Ranged units feel cheap. I've had them not even try to find me at times, then shoot me the instant they can see me, including through walls at times. And many of the baddies can run faster than you. Considerably faster. And when it comes to the exploding baddies, that really sucks.

The level design is both nice and leaves a lot to be desired. In my short time playing through the game, I fell through the map at least five different times. One of the times it wasn't even an instant death, I just saw the game world float out of existance and needed to manually reload the save. I also saw the baddies fall through the world a number of times. The levels themselves felt reasonably well built in terms of layout and lighting, though they also felt fairly empty too. And a others said, it's a very linear game. You go into a room, some silly looking energy field goes up (though not always), and swarms of baddies come at out. The spawning sucks. I went into a room to have some cover from one of the waves and found that it was one of their spawning locations for that wave. On the plus side, you always know when a new wave is about to start because the game always saves just before go far enough into a room to trigger it. And after a wave it over you generally can find enough medpacks to get you back up or close to full health.

Oh, and don't even bother trying to rebind your keys, cause you can't. I ended up going into my keyboards settings to set the keys to what I wanted. And there is no point to the reload bind, as there is no reload for any of the guns...

I can't recommend this game. It just wasn't fun for me. If the AI wasn't so lame/cheap and if the levels didn't have so many holes for me to fall through so often, I probably would have had a lot more fun. If you must get it, do so on sale.

Alright, my joke review was fun, but I would rather give some legit criticism.

First of all, this game isn't a sin, or the worst thing I've ever played. But it certainly isn't very good.

Let's start with what I like: Most of this game is just kill some enemies to advance. That's fine, it's fun to shoot stuff in this game. The shooing is fast and fairly tight. it's very doom esque in encounters, enemies are fast, come flying out of rooms and walls screaming at you, and you need to react quickly to gun them down. This is where the game shines. The action is fast paced and fun.

However, this is where it all falls apart. The problem is you don't spend most of your time doing this. For the most part you only spend about a minute or two in an engagment, then you can move forward through a now unlocked path. This wouldn't be so bad, if the entire game didn't look exactly the same. Rooms are pretty boring and un-furnished, the halls are all very bland. You have a difficult time remembering where you are / came from, let alone where you need to head next. This really kills the flow of the game.

Another problem is the guns. You get a pretty decent amount of guns, however, they're basically all useless in comparison to your shotgun. The guns need to be reworked to make them all more usefull. It's insane how the shotgun is fast, has a ton of knock-back, has extreme firepower, has basically infinite ammo, has a huge range, and can hit more then one enemy at a time.
